column4: not knowing anything about Grub, would it be smart to edit my menu.lst to add windows?
The better bet would be to let it try to add it automatically.
I tried the "update-grub" and then using install disk with rescue mode as I found in the wiki, but nothing helped.
Dang.  Is it a weird setup somehow?  (slave drives or the like?)
Ubuntu is on IDE master (hda) (on hda1) and Windows is on IDE slave (hdb) (on hdb1)

That might do it, not sure.  Well, you can always try; if you understand what you're doing at all the worst you'll do is make a grub entry for Windows that doesn't boot, which is where you're at now anyway.
I don't know anything ;-) but I read the wiki and there's an example in the menu.lst and I feel like I can add a new "section" for windows.
Go for it then, and good luck!
You probably have a default set.  a) do you even see a menu at boot time at all?
(It would be helpful if the pastebin had the entire file)
if I press esc on time, i see it, I can choose different options, but chosing my "Windows XP" just made the computer reboot.
What do you have installed on the MBR of hdb?
Okay, so it's trying to chainload to the other drive, but what's in the other drive's bootloader?
the other drive contains ubuntu. (IDE master (hda)   #1 primary /media/hda1)
I don't think we're communicating very well.  Isn't Ubuntu on the drive you're messing with the grub on?
Okay, and what's on the master boot record of the second drive?
the second drive is hdb and hdb1 contains a fresh Windows XP profesional
Fresh?  Okay, then it should have the Windows bootloader okay too...  Does it give you any sort of output about what's going on when it goes into the reboot on selection?
I have no clue what is chain +1 (I just copied it from the example in the same menu.lst) And when I choose the option "Windows XP" the screen blacks and the computer reboots
This might be a "Windows is dumb" situation.  I wonder what would happen if the drive with Windows was rigged up as the master rather than the slave.
do I have to change the jumpers on the disk? (phisically?)
To test that theory, yes.
okay, i'm trying that now! thanks for the help :-)
